sentence: Two identical rubber hands were positioned on the table and tilted 30° upwards at the front; these rubber hands were placed next to each other at the same distance from the real hand (Fig. 1A).

They were then asked to relax and wiggle their fingers to break the illusion and prevent muscle numbness before the next trial began; another auditory cue indicated the start of the next trial (Fig. 1B).

The congruence between the materials touching the rubber hands and the real hand (texture congruence) was manipulated by attaching either firm plastic or polyethylene foam to the robot hands’ tips, which entailed differences in tactile roughness and hardness (i.e., smooth vs. greater surface friction and soft vs. hard material; Fig. 1C).
Model-averaged posterior distributions of specific effects are shown (Fig. 2C).

As Fig. 3B shows, all comparisons between the “Left texture incongruent” and “Right texture incongruent” conditions were significant: 50 ms (t(20) = 7.203, p < .001, d = 0.942), 100 ms (t(20) = 7.914, p < .001, d = 1.762), and 200 ms (t(20) = 4.519, p < .001, d = 1.128).
Model-averaged posterior distributions of specific effects are shown (Fig. 3C).
The authors thank Martti Mercurio for designing the stimulation robots and the program that controls them, and Mattias Karlén for his assistance with the illustration presented in Fig. 1.
Two identical rubber hands were positioned on the table and tilted 30° upwards at the front; these rubber hands were placed next to each other at the same distance from the real hand (Fig. 1A).

They were then asked to relax and wiggle their fingers to break the illusion and prevent muscle numbness before the next trial began; another auditory cue indicated the start of the next trial (Fig. 1B).

The congruence between the materials touching the rubber hands and the real hand (texture congruence) was manipulated by attaching either firm plastic or polyethylene foam to the robot hands’ tips, which entailed differences in tactile roughness and hardness (i.e., smooth vs. greater surface friction and soft vs. hard material; Fig. 1C).
Model-averaged posterior distributions of specific effects are shown (Fig. 2C).

As Fig. 3B shows, all comparisons between the “Left texture incongruent” and “Right texture incongruent” conditions were significant: 50 ms (t(20) = 7.203, p < .001, d = 0.942), 100 ms (t(20) = 7.914, p < .001, d = 1.762), and 200 ms (t(20) = 4.519, p < .001, d = 1.128).
Model-averaged posterior distributions of specific effects are shown (Fig. 3C).
The authors thank Martti Mercurio for designing the stimulation robots and the program that controls them, and Mattias Karlén for his assistance with the illustration presented in Fig. 1.
